Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 07:30PM - edited Jul 8, 2010 07:31PM by LC815 Before I was diagnosed the first time, I was in an abusive marriage. I had three children in three and a half years and my husband (when he wasn't controlling me or abusing me physically and emotionally) was traveling/working.  I realized, when my youngest was three years old that something needed to change, but I really didn't know how to go about it.  I saw a therapist regularly and I remember coming to her with a decision.  I had decided to stay in the marriage for my children.  I was strong enough to endure whatever I needed to in order to keep their lives intact. This very wise therapist thought for a moment and then told me the earth shattering truth.  However  thought I could suppress my emotions, they would surface in another way.  She predicted that if I didn't get out of my marriage that my stress would manifest itself physically.  She never used the scary word "cancer" but she did mention lupus and fibromyalgia.  I did get out of the marriage, but the stress emotionally flattened me.  Four years later, I felt a lump and there my cancer story begins. I truly believe that the stress of my young adult life and being with my ex-husband caused my cancer.  In any case, it weakened me enough to let it flourish. Now, Stage IV, my ex-husband is decreasing my alimony and using insane and convoluted reasons to do so.  After reading this thread, I am reminded that this could lend a hand in progression.  Thank you for reminding me to relax, let it go, meditate, take Ativan, whatever I need to do to lessen my stress. Peace to us all. LC

Posts.Content: LC815 wrote: Hi everyone, I'm feeling guilty that I've been off the boards or just lurking for the last month or two.  Things are wild in my house right now with a daughter graduating from high school and two others making me slightly nuts with just being their teenaged selves.  I wanted to share my recent preliminary scan news that after four rounds of Taxol/Avastin, my "too numerous to count" liver lesions show "possible regression" and that the radiologist pronounced my recent scan to be "stable."  These scan results are tentative . . . I just heard the news from my primary care provider and see the onc on Tuesday.  I'm happy, though! Yay!  Side effects are still manageable (although I'd like to bite into a meal now and then and be able to predict what it might taste like), and I'm approaching the end of a school year able to continue to teach my darling, dyslexic, needy high school students full time. I've been reading some posts from new members, and I can't believe I'm going to say this (it sounds so trite) but my Stage IV diagnosis has changed my life (duh).  Oh, don't get me wrong, I'd trade it in a heartbeat, and there are days when I can't stop crying but days when I grin from ear to ear just to be alive.  Today was one of them.  My daughter had her Senior Prom tonight and I was so happy to be with her and her adorable boyfriend on a beautiful evening . . . taking pictures . . . and being there for her.  I'm fat, bald and my feet feel funny.  I'm up at 5:00 a.m., unable to sleep, but I'm here and I am thankful for all of you.  Where on earth would I be able to post these thoughts if it wasn't for you? Love and peace to all, Linda from Baltimore P.S.  Got my tumor marker stats today . . . down from 311 to 188!!  (No matter what you think of their validity, I'm glad they're going down instead of up!)  Have a wonderful, wonderful weekend everyone.  I hope that you get rest, peace, fun, sun, whatever you need.  Original Diagnosis 5/04, 2.5 cm. Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 06:27PM LC815 wrote: Kay, I feel so badly when I think of your post in the middle of the night.  I wish I had been there for you, but I had downed quite a bit of wine and a bawdy historical novel and was asleep. Yesterday, I called my primary care provider and demanded that she write me a scrip for a large amount of Ativan.  (Funny thing is, she's my best friend since high school.)  Before this, I was hording them and not taking them when I thought I could tough it out.  I couldn't.  She was worried about me "relying" on it, but then when I pointed out I've got STAGE IV BREAST CANCER and that addiction to Ativan would be the least of my problems, she dished it out. Also, when I take an Ativan in the morning, it opens my mind to Positive Possibilities which I do not think about when I'm overly anxious.  I also think anxiety builds upon itself.  It's like a bad headache.  If you don't get rid of it when it first comes upon you, it just gets worse and worse.   Same PCP (and best friend) went to hear Lilly Shockley of Johns Hopkins speak about a month ago at a BC forum.  Our docs are finally being informed about our depression and anxiety and treatments needed for both.  Make sure your onc and the rest of your medical team know how you are feeling.   It is the "new thing" in oncology to treat the mind as well as the disease.  Sheesh.  Why don't they just ask us? ~Linda from Baltimore P.S.  Until you get that Ativan prescription, Benadryl works wonders.

Posts.Content: LC815 wrote: Hi y'all. Last weekend, I took to my bed.  I was depressed, miserable and borderline suicidal.  No, I really wouldn't have gone through with it; I live for my daughters.  However, I was thinking, "What's the point with all this miserable treatment -- if I'm going to go, why not just go?" Then I remembered something Elaine D posted once.  That as miserable as this treatment seems to be, we will look back and WISH we felt this good.  Elaine is a wise, wise woman. I started to look at my SE's as merely annoying, not debilitating.  I slowly started to climb out of the abyss  I enjoyed hanging out with my two younger girls (14 and 17) and my oldest (18) called from college. I got scan results back yesterday.  STABLE!!!  Now, in the past, when I've gotten "no progression of disease", I've been kind of disappointed.  Why not NED?  But, right now, I'm feeling peace I haven't felt in quite awhile. I'm doing a lot of "holding in the light" tonight (it's a Quaker thing) for our sisters that aren't doing faring well this week.  Love you all and wish you peace, LC Original Diagnosis 5/04, 2.5 cm. Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2009 01:39PM LC815 wrote: Lisa, I feel your pain -- on my first dx, my ex-husband notified all our friends and family about my dx via a mass email.  Yep, my very own cancer and I can't be the one to tell (OR NOT) others.  This go 'round, he's all in a dither because I've been with a wonderful man for almost eight years and his problem the other day was, "When you take a turn for the worst, will we all have to be at your bed side with Your DBF and his children?"  Like, his discomfort at my love for another is first and foremost.  During the first dx, I actually yelled at him, "Get your own cancer!" THEN, my idiot (but beloved) seventeen-year-old daughter was ragging on me a few days ago because she HAD TO HAVE a new computer (not get the old one fixed, as I wanted).  I tried to gently remind her that I had gotten some bad news on Friday (chemo -- full steam ahead) and she actually said to me, "Mother, this isn't about YOU."   Lo and behold, we got the computer fixed for free and I made her say, "I was wrong, you were right.  I apologize."  So childish of me, I know. The exact scene that played out this summer with your SIL and her comment that she wished she could have her family for two hours without cancer was played by a good friend's sister recently.  GF's husband had diabetes that is hard to control, and they had just come from a doctor's appointment when GF's sister called to require something of GF.  When GF explained she couldn't be there for her, GF's sister responded, 'Dear God, does it always have to be about the diabetes?!" I think your SIL is mad at the whole world.  What a way to live, huh?  Almost makes a girl glad she's got Stage IV  BC and not Terminal Anger. Peace, Linda

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 05:14PM LC815 wrote: You all are the best!  The biopsy went off without a hitch.  The procedure took ten minutes, but I had to be there two hours ahead of time, then they were an hour late.  Three hour recovery!  Aacckk.  No results until next week, but I went over to Medical Oncology to see if I could see my onc.  Well, I had forgotten it was moving day -- they're moving their offices down the hall, so they weren't seeing patients.  Except my wonderful medical assistant, Julie.  She got Paula, the nurse practitioner and they both pronounced me "not too bad looking."  Hey, when you're jaundiced, you'll take it.  Paula said, "I've seen a lot worse" and I told her that would get me through the weekend. Heartwarming story:  Yesterday, at school, I was keeping it together -- barely.  A friend and fellow teacher sees me and text me to go home, they've got my last two classes covered.  I responded that I was fine, I could get through, but that she was good to think of me.  Next thing I know, I'm in the middle of teaching my yearbook class and my other friend comes in (big guy, 6'3" or so) and sits in my chair.  Motions me to leave.  I tell him to get out of my chair (my kids all know this is my pet peeve) and he says, "No way.  I've got the next two periods free."  I cave, go home, and sleep from about 4:30 p.m. until I had to be up for my procedure today.  I love those people. LC

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 07:57PM - edited May 25, 2010 08:00PM by LC815 I had five years, too.  My surgeon told me when I was first diagnosed, "You'll have the year from hell and then you'll do fine with this disease."  I had a mastectomy, reconstruction, chemo (even though my onc said it was only going to improve my chances of recurrance by 16%).  Five years of Tamoxifen then Arimidex.   So, I'm on Arimidex and my periods come back (after being gone for 4+ years).  I call my onc.  Nurse practitioner returns call.  "Oh, you can't be on Arimidex if you're not menopausal.  Stop taking it."  Six months later:  On a Thursday I find lump in breast that isn't there anymore. Next day, see Surgeon.  Tuesday, lumpectomy.  A week later, "routine PET" before radiation.  Frickin' Stage IV.   What a beast. Two sub-centimeter lesions to liver.  Piece of cake, right?  Lupron shot, start Arimidex. Oopherectomy. CT scan.  Liver now RIDDLED with sub-centimeter lesions "too many to count".  Original two measure 1cm and 1.3 cm.  F.   Clinical trial: Taxol/Avastin.  Workin' way too slow for my taste but onc is pleased. Thanks for letting ME vent on your post, Lisa. I liked what you posted on Fitztwins "cancer girl" post tonight.  You really brought home how we all feel.  Cheated.  Pissed.  But there are good days.  For instance, I'm totally blowing off a clinical trial-mandated visit to my onc to see my daughter win the Senior Art Award at her school.  Ha! You'll have many more than five years.  I hope you have an aggressive onc and he/she is up on the latest.  My onc gave me "a decade" and I am sooo out to prove him wrong.  Two decades is my bare minimum.  I'm 48.  I've got three teenaged daughters and I'll be damned if I don't see them on to adulthood before I go. We ain't going down without a SERIOUS fight!!  Right,ladies!?

Posts.Content: LC815 wrote: Today: CA 15-3 markers up again.  So, I met with my onc and it looks like my ER+ tumor isn't really.  He likened it to a door that has a lock but is unlocked . . . meaning just because I've got the receptors, it doesn't mean they actually function.  Three months of worthless (to me) Arimidex, on to a clinical trial.  Taxol + Avastin or two other drugs + Avastin.  Anyone had any experience with this?  I tolerated Taxol the first time pretty well and he said Avastin has very few side effects.  I wanted the oral-no-hair-loss chemo but the trial has to be the first chemo protocol for admission.  There goes the hair.  The daughters are sad, but I've promised to kick some cancer a@@.  The one thing that shocked me is when I read the trial notes, I see that I could be taking this chemo until 1. It doesn't work any more or 2. I can't tolerate the side effects.  There was no mention in the paperwork of stopping when NED (although my onc said I could make that decision).   SOOOO very different from my first dx when I just went through a few rounds and then stopped.  Bald for the rest of my life?  I never considered it until today.  (How silly and vain of me.) Crap.  I hoped to get some years out of hormonals, and I couldn't even get three months.  I'm going to open some wine and start my pity party.  Everyone's invited!  Original Diagnosis 5/04, 2.5 cm. Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 07:42PM LC815 wrote: Cat, I'm totally with you.  I'm so sick of hearing that Sheryl, Melinda, Christina and all those ladies "successfully battled breast cancer."  Yes, they won the battle, and damn, I sure hope they win the war, but it's never over.  Elizabeth Edwards has uttered the only honest Stage IV words I've heard in the media, "I have stopped praying for a miracle and just pray that I can make the most of the time I have left," (or something to that effect). I really get ticked at the UnderArmour ad on this site, "I looked cancer in the face and told him, 'You've picked the wrong girl.'"  Cancer doesn't have a FACE and if it did, it's not a HIM (unless you're a him) and last time I checked, when one is forty nine years old, she's not a GIRL!  This ad makes it seem like we have a flippin' CHOICE in the matter -- like if we fight hard enough we can win.  (Moderators, if you're checking out this post, take this to heart). There was a nice little article in the cancer-centered magazine in my doctors office about women living well with metastatic disease . . . however, the people pictured were older ladies with silver hair and big smiles.  I thought about all of the young women on this site . . . mets don't only happen when you're over sixty-five! One of our Metsters has written to Oprah and has gotten no response.  Nope.  Oprah doesn't want to touch this topic.  No happy ending. Damn, I could go on and on. Peace y'all, LC

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 05:54PM LC815 wrote: MzJoy, I know how you feel.  I always said, "I have great genes on my side."  My great aunt lived until 102, My great grandmother died at 97.  One grandparent died of emphysema after smoking his whole life.  (I've never had one cigarette.)  Other three grandparents lived into their late eighties/early nineties.  My mother is 70 and works as a chef 5-6 days a week.  My father is in his second career and still swims at 69.   So what about me?  Why me?  No breast cancer (that I was aware of) in my family.  Okay, I could handle it the first time, but this second stage IV dx?  WTF? I, too, want to get AT LEAST eight years out of this.  But that sentence that I've just written terrifies me.  Eight years?  That's it?  I'm 48 years old.  I can tell you that the last eight years went by in a blink, but I feel paralyzed about these next eight.  (The violins are out, the pity party has started -- but has it really ever ended since October?) Nicole, I am sorry I hijacked your thread. I'm sorry.  If I haven't said it already, thank you for posting so that all of these wonderful women could post their survival stories. HOPE -- WE NEED MORE OF IT!!

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2010 09:32PM LC815 wrote: Hi Nicole, I've been on Taxol/Avastin since January and it has been okay . . . stable with some regression to my liver mets.  I'm planning on ending next month because my SE's have been pretty bad.  I think that as long as you feel good and it's working . . . keep on!  Do you have any other mets?  If your liver mets are completely gone, then there's nothing to hit with cryoablation, I don't think.  A lot of oncs don't talk cryoablation or site specific treatments because Stage IV is a systemic disease and they feel it's better to treat the whole body than one specific area. I don't know if you're still working, but I know that the infusion of Taxol/Avastin takes a long time.  For me, it meant half days at work three Fridays of every month.  I quickly ran out of sick time, but my school administration was really good to me.  Maybe your onc could decrease your dosage or frequency so that you could spend less time "in the chair." Peace, LC

Posts.Content: LC815 wrote: I had my sixteenth Taxol/Avastin treatment today.  As usual, I was given Benadryl.  Even though I slept most of the morning, (infusion was at 1:00 p.m.), I fell asleep for most of the treatment.  Went home, slept some more. Then, this evening, I went to dinner with friends.  Normally, the Deacdron kicks in and I'm fine.  People, I was so out of it, that I didn't even know where I was.  My BF has a Mazda Miata, but we had his sister and niece with us, so he drove their car.  He did an awesome job parallel parking, so he said, "You should see me in the Miata."  I responded, "We're in the Miata."  In fact, I said it TWICE.  The Miata is a two-seater, so we couldn't possibly be in that car. Then, all night long, I used words incorrectly, like "textbook" for "facebook."  Also, the other day BEFORE my treatment, I was sitting in our school's auditorium watching a presentation, and a feeling came over me like I had no idea who I was or why I was there.  It wasn't all-consuming, so I didn't have an "episode" or anything, thank goodness. Anyone else experience this dementia-like feeling?  I always thought chemo brain was just a short term memory thing, nothing like this. P.S. On the bright side:  TM's continue to fall, slowly but surely.  Went from 188 to 157 this month.  Beats the alternative! Original Diagnosis 5/04, 2.5 cm. Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2010 01:42AM LC815 wrote: Lisa, A message from "Captain Obvious" -- we all know that "white coat syndrome" is totally real.  My oncologist is one that people are on a waiting list to see.  Does that mean I love him? No.  At this point, I've got so many quesitons. Here's this goofy thing that comes over me when I see my onc.  I have this need to "please", I guess, so I put my game face on and I feel like I'm totally fine.  I'm not faking it, I really feel good when I see him -- that means a lot of the things I've worried about, I don't even bring up.   I don't think that getting a second opinion was your responsibility in your case. If it were, you can be damn sure your insurance company would have made you do it.  "White coat syndrome" is a common label in the oncology department. Everytime my blood pressure is high, my research nurse brings it up. "WCS" also pertains to having a figure of authority, in a white lab coat, telling you "the truth.' Most patients are intimidated by this, even knowlegeable ones. It can't hurt to investigate. Peace, Linda C

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2010 12:29AM LC815 wrote: Lisa, As you know from my other thread, the same thing happened to me.  Unfortunately, the standard of care (as I understand it) is Tamoxifen for five years, then nothing.  Statistics show that after five years, Tamoxifen's effectiveness is equal to no treatment at all.  So, oncs usually stop treatment then.  If you're not having your periods, your next med is Arimidex. I started my periods again on Arimidex and they took me off everything.  No oopherectomy, no lupron shots, nothing. I guess they thought I was "cured."  To be honest, I thought the same thing.  I had reached the five year mark. Six months later, palbable lump and spread to liver.  I'm not sure what to do.  I talked to my surgeon and he backed up the onc on the protocol.  I trust him implicitly, but they are both doctors and I'm not in "the club." Linda C.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 11:00PM LC815 wrote: MJ,' That is freaking amazing.  I can't believe these people have a license to practice medicine.  When I had my first palpable lump, I walked around with it for awhile, stupid and happy.  The minute my PCP had a look at it (I was in for an ear infection), the sh!t hit the fan and in about a week and a half I was under the knife for a mastectomy.  This last time -- I felt the lump on a Thursday, saw my surgeon on Friday and the following Tuesday he did a lumpectomy under local anesthesia.  Love that guy.  It's the aftermath that got me.  He said during my initial diagnosis, "You'll have the year from hell, then it will be over."  Oh . . . if only.  Recurrance: Onc said,"Before your radiation, we'll do a routine PET, nothing to worry about, it'll be clear"  Oh . . . if only.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 01:21PM LC815 wrote: Thanks for the welcome, everyone.  I've been teetering between denial and terror at facing cancer these days.  I feel badly for not being there for you, but in the back of my mind the whole time was this discussion board.  God bless you all! My TM's started at 140 with rediagnosis and went up to 456.  The lowest they've been is 66 since then.  I'm going to push to keep chemo at bay for awhile.  I'm on Tamoxifen, and besides some nausea, I'm doing well . . . physically. Emotionally, I've been at loose ends.  I was out of my Ativan, and last weekend I really thought I was going to have a breakdown.  Sleepless nights, unsuccessfully self-medicating with wine, deep despair.  At one point I thought, "Why bother fighting if I have to feel like this?"  I have three teenage girls, and that was the only thing that got me out of bed each day.   First Ativan was last night, I got a great night's sleep and an inclement weather day off today (I am a teacher).  Hopefully the downward spiral is taking an upward turn. Peace, LC

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2010 01:39AM LC815 wrote: Renee, I think you should invest in a commercial beach umbrella (the heavy canvas kind) or a sturdy "beach tent" (maybe from L.L. Bean, REI or Eddie Bauer) with a nice fully reclining beach chair.  If these are too expensive,checkout eBay or CraigsList.  At my beach, you can rent an umbrella for the day or week.  If you love the beach, a shady spot with a lovely book can be a precursor to a great beach nap AND you can be with your family.  A packed cooler with lots of water and snacks is good, too.  Pat, Why are you taking the Decadron?  I teach full time, so sometimes I think I have t take it to get through the day.  Mly research nurse told me to take it every other day to minimize the SEs.  My prescription is 8 mg (2 pills), but I usually take it "as needed."  4 mg twice a week is good enough to do my job. I have always been a very "low energy" person.  It's so worse, now.  I just try to do ONE "productive thing" a day (after my nap, of course).   That may be unloading/loading the diswasher, a load of laundry, contacting the IRS about my payment (BTW, that was today), cleaning my bedroom, etc.  Just ONE. Now, here's a question that I think I'm going to post on the forum . . .my radio station runs commercials about an "energy patch" that's better than caffeine, energy drinks or energy shots.  Anyone heard of this? Peace, Linda C.

DD laughed out loud, "Mom, we're a bunch of teenage girls, we don't notice things like weeds in the driveway."  If I can keep the sink clear, I'm ahead of the game. Laundry, forget about it.  It's in the basement near the nasty cat box and I can't bear to go down there.  I'm approaching my last week of school, so things might settle down a bit for awhile, but I honestly don't know what I'm going to to come September. Right now,I feel so lousy on Monday and Tuesday during school, that I feel that by the time I go back at the end of summer, that bad stretch will go until Wednesday (at least!) I really don't want to give up teaching.  I'm afraid I'll never get out of my bed.  Taxol/Avastin is supposed to be very do-able, and I'm sure they are, but right now they're kicking my butt. I'm nauseated without chemo!  I've been on Taxol/Avastin since January, I would love, love, love to meet NED before school starts at the end of August.  A girl can dream can't she?

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 09:26PM LC815 wrote: Hi Elaine, I'm just chiming in with support and hugs for you. Also, with unprofessional, anecdotal advice!  My ex-husband suffers from bi-polar disease and I always say that if he were on medicaiton, we might still be married today.  His situation, of course, is completely different than your daughter's, but one thing caught my eye:  the fact that your daughter has tried meds and therapy before, but on a limited basis.  You know (and she will too, in time) that treatment for depression is just like any other disease . . . it takes commitment.  Imagine if we gave up chemo after two or three sessions.  The thing I've found with anti-depressants is that they are so subtle that the patient may not realize how much better they're getting until that one "ah-hah" day when everything seems to go right!  They, then, need to be careful and give the meds the credit.  My ex always thought HE was handling things better and that he didn't need the meds anymore.  Aughhh!  It was the meds that got him stable! More hugs, LC

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2010 10:17PM LC815 wrote: I call my onc "The Gentle Giant".  He's a big guy, very smart, but I can tell when he's struggling to tell me something.  I think that he thinks, "Jeez, I'm already putting her through chemo, am I going to now tell her she's got to walk five miles a day?"  But, when I brought up my unhappiness at my weight gain and my propensity to get in bed when I'm tired instead of working through it, he said, "I think you should get a project."  Then, we did talk about this for awhile. Sometimes, I think oncs are concentrating on the major problem, and I think that if you're okay with that, then be comforted to know that they're doing what they do best. (I found out the other day that my onc can't type or text which is why there were times I didn't have emails answered.  I laughed and said, "Well, I guess I'm glad he's good at oncology!")  Our other team members -- PCPs, nutritionists, etc. can focus on their specialties.  All that having been said, I think five minutes is too short for an appointment.  How does he act if you bring questions?  Patient or impatient?  Please get a second opinion if you are uncomfortable.  No doctor worth his white coat would balk at you getting one.  Peace, LC

Posts.Content: LC815 wrote: Well, NED has not yet come to call, but the stable boy and Little Reggie (Regression Dude) are here!  CT showed nothing new, no spread to other places, no huge differences, but onc says "things are getting smaller."  TM CA 15-3 went down from 157 to 130. So, the plan is that if my next scan in August shows the same thing, I will have had 24 tx of Taxol/Avastin and he's planning on either significantly reducing the Taxol OR eliminating it and keeping me on the Avastin.  Also, I had no luck with Arimidex, but I think Tamoxifen did the job for the five years I took it, so he might put me back on that. Anyone here on Avastin only?! Peace, Linda C Original Diagnosis 5/04, 2.5 cm. Stage IIB, 2/14 nodes. 9/09 local recurrance and liver mets.
